WaniKani_Reading_Mnemonic:
To remember ãµ we'll use the word "fool."
Think of those jokes, where someone says something, then ends with a loud "NOTTTT!" Someone is doing that to you, over and over. What is that person? That person is a fool (ãµ).
WaniKani_Reading_Info: Be sure to feel irritated at that person. Think in your head as they're telling these dumb "not" jokes how much of a fool they are... and how much of a fool you are for sitting here and listening to them.

origin_of_ch_char_book: The king and the aristocrats used a huge bronze cauldron for ceremonies. To have a cracked or deformed cauldron was considered to be very bad luck. Since the bronze cauldron was sacred, if it were ruined, they would have shouted â€œBu (no) !â€ and this became the origin of the meaning of the word today as â€œnoâ€ or â€œforbiddenâ€ (ä¸, bu, no; not). The original shape of this character was the ceremonial cup (æ¯, bei, cup) with three legs which were distorted. The three legs represent â€˜Heaven, Human, Earthâ€™, and the distortion of these three legs means â€˜bad luckâ€™, â€˜evilâ€™. It was not easy to make a model of bronzeware with mud or wax. When the model for molding was deformed, people thought it was the sign of evil.,If the vessels were not perfect, it was believed that God would refuse to accept the ceremony. (å¦, fou, deny) In comparison with the above one (ä¸, bu, no; not), this character is added of (å£, kou, mouse) which means â€˜mouseâ€™ or â€˜speakingâ€™. God is speaking not to accept the imperfect ceremony. A huge bronze cauldron with three legs (1046-771 BC)

Used in front of verbs, adjectives and other words to indicate negation or added in front of nouns or nominal morphemes to form adjectives: do not go. not much. illegal. unexpectedly. Inadequate (capable of mediocrity, often used for self-humility). Not published (no need to modify, indelible). Not learning and skillless. uninvited guest.
Use it alone to make a negative answer: No, I don't know.
Used at the end of the sentence to express a question: Is he in good health now?
